questions.text: The most common valvular heart disease in pregnancy is ______
questions.solution:
Mitral stenosis is the most common valvular heart disease in pregnancy.

The commonest cardiac lesions are of rheumatic origin followed by congenital conditions. The incidence of cardiac lesions is less than 1% amongst hospital deliveries. Rheumatic valvular lesions predominantly include mitral stenosis (80%).

questions.text: What is the commonest congenital valvular lesion observed in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is the commonest congenital valvular lesion observed in pregnancy. Mitral stenosis is the commonest acquired heart lesion during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady with rheumatic mitral stenosis becomes pregnant. At what point during her pregnancy would you be least concerned about her developing cardiac failure?
questions.solution:
Cardiac failure in pregnancy is least likely to occur during 24 weeks, considering the given options.

The order of risk of cardiac failure in pregnancy is immediate postpartum > 2nd stage of labor > 30 weeks > 22 weeks.

Maternal cardiac risk predictors: [Mnemonic: NOPE]

  N-NYHA class >2

  O-Obstructive lesions of left heart (Mitral valve area <2 cm2  or aortic valve area <1.5 cm2, peak LV outflow tract gradient >30 mmHg)

  P-Prior cardiac events before pregnancy

  E-Ejection fraction <40%

Scoring systems used to calculate risk are Cardiac Disease in Pregnancy (CARPREG) and ZAHARA scores.

questions.text: An intern posted in the antenatal OPD auscultates a patient who came for her routine checkup. Presence of which of the following features would not suggest a physiological change of pregnancy?

choices.text: Ejection systolic murmur at left sternal border
Continuous murmur at  2nd to 4th intercostal space

questions.solution:
Late systolic murmur is pathological in pregnancy.

CVS physiological changes in pregnancy:

  • Pulse rate: Increases
  • Diastolic BP: Decreases
  • S1: Loud and split
  • S2:Normal
  • S3:prominent (occasional)
  • Jugular venous distension and venous hum
  • Murmurs
    • Ejection systolic murmur at left sternal border.
    • Continous murmur at 2nd-4th intercostal space (known as mammary souffle)
  • Heart is displaced upwards and to the left
  • ECG changes
    • Left axis deviation (due to elevation of diaphragm)
    • T wave inversion, biatrial enlargement
    • Mild ST changes in the inferior leads
    • Premature atrial and ventricular contractions are relatively frequent.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an absolute indication for therapeutic termination of pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Prosthetic valve replacement is not an indication for therapeutic termination as it comes under the WHO category risk 3. Only conditions included under WHO category risk 4 are considered as indications for termination of pregnancy.

WHO class 4 comprises of diseases with very high risk of maternal mortality or severe morbidity, such as:

  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension
  • Severe systemic ventricular dysfunction (NYHA III-IV or LVEF 30-40%)
  • Previous peripartum cardiomyopathy with any residual impairment of left ventricular function
  • Severe left heart obstruction
  • Marfan syndrome with aorta dilated >40 mm

Termination of pregnancy is also advised in patients with Eisenmenger syndrome.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with heart failure planned for valve replacement surgery is posted for cesarean section. Which of the following is not a cardiac indication for cesarean delivery?
questions.solution:
Primary pulmonary hypertension is not a cardiac indication for caesarean delivery.

In primary pulmonary hypertension, maternal mortality is about 50% and the majority die (75%) postpartum.

Simpson’s criteria for cesarean delivery for cardiac disease in pregnancy:

  • Dilated aortic root >4 cm or aortic aneurysm
  • Acute severe congestive heart failure
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Severe symptomatic aortic stenosis
  • Warfarin administration within 2 weeks of delivery
  • Need for emergency valve replacement immediately after delivery

Coarctation of the aorta and aortic dissection are other indications for cesarean delivery.

In general, vaginal delivery is preferred, and labor induction is usually safe. Cesarean delivery is limited to obstetric indications, and considerations are given for the specific cardiac lesions only. Epidural anesthesia is given during LSCS in heart disease. The major problem with epidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especially dangerous in women with intracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes from right to left and bypasses the lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia should be given.

questions.text: You are performing CPR on a woman who is 38-weeks pregnant. She was admitted to the emergency after a massive pulmonary embolism led to cardio-pulmonary arrest. Despite the initial management of airway, oxygenation and vasopressor support, there is no improvement. What is the cut off time  for perimortem cesarean delivery in this patient?
questions.solution:
Perimortem cesarean delivery should be considered if there is no return of spontaneous circulation in 5 minutes, according to the AHA 2020 Guidelines. 

The goal of perimortem cesarean section (PMCS) should be primarily aimed at saving the life of the mother. PMCS improves maternal survival by decreasing compression of the IVC by the gravid uterus. This improves venous return and diaphragmatic displacement, which in turn improves respiratory dynamics.

questions.text: A G2P1 patient with mitral valve prolapse goes into labor. Which of the following should not be done in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Cut short second stage of labour using ventouse
Trendelenburg position during first stage of labor

questions.solution:
Lateral recumbent position is advised during the first stage of labor in this patient.

Management of labor in patients with heart disease:

First stage:

  • Lateral recumbent or propped up position
  • Oxygen administration (5 to 6 L/min)
  • Analgesia by epidural
  • Fluids should not be infused more than 75 ml/h
  • Prophylactic antibiotics for bacterial endocarditis during labour and 48 h after delivery
  • Central venous pressure monitoring

Second stage:

  • No maternal pushing
  • Cut short second stage by forceps or ventouse under pudendal and/or perineal block anaesthsia
  • The benefit of avoiding haemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighed against an increased risk of perineal trauma, haemorrhage and fetal head injury with forceps or vacuum delivery.

Third stage:

  • Oxytocin by infusion
  • IV frusemide if needed

questions.text: A pregnant woman with cardiac disease is on warfarin therapy. When will the final switch to heparin be advised?
questions.solution:
The final switch to heparin in a pregnant women is advised at 36 weeks of pregnancy and is continued till 7 days postpartum.

This switch is made from warfarin to heparin at 36 weeks, as warfarin is a strong anticoagulant which can cause post partum hemorrhage in the mother at the time of labour and can also cross the placenta into the fetal blood and can increase the risk of intracranial hemorrhage in the fetus

The below given algorithm is followed for administration of anticoagulants in a pregnant female:

Period of pregnancy Anticoagulation of choice
First trimester

If dose of warfarin < 5mg/day– continue warfarin till 36 weeks 

If dose of warfarin > 5mg /day or warfarin embryopathy present – replace it with heparin / LMWH
From 12 weeks to 36 weeks warfarin
At 36 weeks Switch to LMWH
1 week before EDD / 3 days before EDD Switch to UFH (as LMWH have longer T1/2– increased chances of PPH)
On the day of delivery Stop all anticoagulant
6 hrs after vaginal delivery / 6-12 hrs after cesarean   Restart UFH and Warfarin. When INR is 2.5 to 3 withdraw UFH & continue warfarin

LMWH- low molecular weight heparin
UFH- Unfractionated heparin

questions.text: A 28-year-old G2P1 was admitted to the labor room at 38 weeks of gestation. She is a known case of mitral valve prolapse.  Which of the following is the best for managing the second stage of labor in this patient ?
questions.solution:
The best technique for managing the second stage of labor in a patient with heart disease is using ventouse.

For most cardiac patients, vaginal delivery is preferred and cesarean section is reserved for obstetric indications since the cesarean section is associated with more blood loss and higher thromboembolic and infection risk. If vaginal delivery is selected as the mode of choice, it will be conducted with the laboring woman in an upright position, or in the left decubitus position. This minimizes aortocaval compression.

Active pushing during the second stage may also be limited, depending on the degree of cardiac compromise. In moderate to severe cardiac disease, it may be prudent to completely avoid an active second stage. Regional anesthesia can be used to allow the fetal head to descend to the perineum without active pushing. Delivery can be further facilitated by forceps or vacuum extraction. 

The benefit of avoiding hemodynamic fluctuations resulting from pushing must be weighed against an increased risk of perineal trauma, hemorrhage, and fetal head injury with forceps or vacuum delivery.

Some journals report that ventouse is preferable to forceps, as it can be applied without putting the patient in lithotomy position (raising the legs increases the cardiac load) however it is controversial.

questions.text: General anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia in pregnant women with ______
questions.solution:
In pregnant ladies with intracardiac shunts, general anesthesia is the preferable mode of analgesia.

The major problem with epidural/spinal analgesia is maternal hypotension. This is especially dangerous in women with intracardiac shunts in whom flow may be reversed (blood passes from right to left and bypasses the lungs). So in case of a shunt lesion, only general anesthesia should be given.

Note: Aortic stenosis will also be affected by the hypotension caused by epidural/spinal analgesia. However, in aortic stenosis, slow epidural anesthesia is adequate and doesn't compromise ventricular preload. Only a few severe cases of aortic stenosis warrant GA. Hence, in the context of this MCQ, 'intracardiac shunts' would be the most appropriate answer.

questions.text: A pregnant lady with mitral stenosis requires anticoagulation. Which of the following statements is false regarding her management?

choices.text: LMWH or UFH is used until 13 weeks of pregnancy
From 13 weeks till close to delivery substitute UFH with warfarin
Following vaginal delivery, anticoagulation with LMWH or UFH is restarted after 6 hours

questions.solution:
Warfarin is not contraindicated during lactation.

Warfarin, low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH), unfractionated heparin (UFH) do not accumulate in breast milk. They do not induce an anticoagulant effect in the infant.

The choice of anticoagulants is the main problem in pregnancy due to the following reasons:

  • Warfarin: Although safe for the mother, can lead to warfarin embryopathy, miscarriage, IUGR, and stillbirths.
  • Heparin: It is safe for the fetus as it does not cross the placenta but less effective than warfarin.
  • LMWH: Inadequate and ACOG does not recommend its use in pregnant women with prosthetic heart valves.

Period of gestation

Anticoagulant

Till 12 completed weeks

LMWH or UFH

13 to 36 weeks

Warfarin

36 weeks to 6 hours before delivery

LMWH or UFH

6 hours after vaginal and 24 hours after cesarian section

LMWH or UFH (ACOG recommendation)

If the patient delivers when the anticoagulant is still effective and bleeds excessively, then protamine sulfate is given intravenously.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in pregnancy?

choices.text: Most affected patients are asymptomatic during pregnancy
Diuretics are generally not used in this patient
She may develop chest pain, palpitations, and syncope
The most common cause for death is cardiac failure

questions.solution:
The most common cause of death in HOCM in pregnant women is ventricular tachyarrhythmias.

Most affected women are asymptomatic, but some patients may develop:

  • Dyspnea
  • Anginal or atypical chest pain
  • Syncope
  • Arrhythmias.

Strenuous exercise is prohibited during pregnancy. Abrupt positional changes are avoided to prevent reflex vasodilation and decrease of preload. Diuretics and vasodilators are generally not used as they decrease preload. If angina develops, beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers are used.

The mode of delivery depends upon obstetric indications and if cesarean section is done, general anesthesia is considered the safest.

questions.text: All are true regarding peripartum cardiomyopathy except _____

choices.text: Development of cardiac failure within 5 months of delivery

questions.solution:
Left ventricular systolic dysfunction is a feature of peripartum cardiomyopathy (also known as postpartum cardiomyopathy) and not diastolic dysfunction.

Peripartum cardiomyopathy (PPCM) is a type of dilated cardiomyopathy. It develops during the last month of pregnancy or within the first 5 months following delivery. 

The predisposing factors include Cardiac gene mutations involving several genes like TTNC1, TTN, and STAT3, Twin pregnancy/ multifetal gestation, Smoking, and Preeclampsia. Other proposed causes include viral myocarditis, abnormal immune response to pregnancy, malnutrition, inflammation, etc.

PPCM is associated with increased secretion of prolactin by the pituitary and antiangiogenic molecule sFlt-1 (soluble fms-like tyrosine kinase) by the placenta at term gestation.

Pearson’s diagnostic criteria for PPCM:

  • Development of cardiac failure in the last month of pregnancy or within 5 months after delivery
  • Absence of an identifiable cause for the cardiac failure
  • Absence of recognizable heart disease prior to the last month of pregnancy, and
  • Left ventricular systolic dysfunction demonstrated by echocardiographic criteria, such as ejection fraction <45% or fractional shortening <30% along with a dilated left ventricle.

Management involves treating the features of heart failure. Bromocriptine has been found useful in this condition. Many women recover within 6 months of delivery, while some continue to have residual effects.

questions.text: Which of the following agents has been proposed to be responsible for peripartum cardiomyopathy?
questions.solution:
Prolactin has been proposed to be responsible for peripartum cardiomyopathy.

Oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin. The resulting 16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism and contractility of cardiomyocytes.

The etiology of peripartum cardiomyopathy remains unknown. Many potential causes have been proposed but are not proven.

  • Viral myocarditis
  • Abnormal immune response to pregnancy
  • Abnormal response to the increased hemodynamic burden of pregnancy
  • Malnutrition
  • Inflammation
  • Apoptosis
  • Prolactin

questions.text: A P1L1 lady presents with complaints of fatigue and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea 3 months after her delivery. On examination, she has pedal edema and echo shows left ventricular systolic dysfunction. Which of the following drugs has shown to be effective for the treatment of her condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of peripartum cardiomyopathy and bromocriptine is effective for its treatment.

Oxidative stress during late pregnancy leads to the proteolytic cleavage of prolactin. The resulting 16-kDa prolactin fragment has been found to be cardiotoxic and can impair the metabolism and contractility of cardiomyocytes. Based on this proposed mechanism, bromocriptine therapy has been suggested because it inhibits prolactin secretion.

questions.text: A 34-year-old lady came to the antenatal OPD with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. Her UPT is positive.  She is a known case of mitral stenosis for 5 years.  Which is the best time to do surgery for mitral stenosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
The best time of surgery for mitral stenosis in pregnancy is between 14–18 weeks.

Balloon valvuloplasty is the procedure of choice for mitral stenosis in pregnancy. Any cardiac surgery in pregnancy should usually be postponed until after delivery, but if required, it can be performed safely in the 2nd trimester.

questions.text: A lady with ventricular septal defect becomes pregnant. Which of the following is not a common complication that is expected to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
Hypertension is a common maternal complication of congenital cardiac disease in pregnancy.

The common maternal complications in patients with congenital cardiac disease include:

  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Arrhythmia
  • Hypertension

questions.text: What is the most common arrhythmia encountered in pregnancy?
questions.solution: The most common arrhythmia seen in reproductive-aged women is paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia.

questions.text:
Women with the highest risk of endocarditis in pregnancy are those with _____
  1. Prosthetic valves
  2. Cyanotic heart disease
  3. Mitral stenosis
  4. Isolated mitral regurgitation
  5. MVP with MR
questions.solution:
Women at the highest risk for endocarditis are those with cyanotic cardiac disease and prosthetic valves.

The American heart association recommends prophylaxis for dental procedures with:

  • Prosthetic valves
  • Unrepaired cyanotic heart defects
  • Valvulopathy after heart transplantation

American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists do not recommend endocarditis prophylaxis for either vaginal or cesarean delivery in the absence of pelvic infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with the highest risk of maternal mortality during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Eisenmenger syndrome is the heart disease with the worst prognosis, having a maternal mortality rate of 50%.

The most common cause of death in Eisenmenger’s syndrome is right ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock. If antenatal diagnosis of Eisenmenger syndrome is made in the first trimester, termination of pregnancy is advised. Eisenmenger syndrome has the highest risk of maternal mortality. However, since mitral stenosis is the most common cardiac condition in pregnancy, it is the most common cause of maternal mortality overall. 

Mitral regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse and pulmonary stenosis are well tolerated during pregnancy. Severe aortic stenosis can be life-threatening. However, women with mild to moderate aortic valve stenosis may have a relatively low-risk pregnancy.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida delivered a full-term male baby by vaginal delivery.  She is a known case of rheumatic mitral stenosis for 4 years. After the delivery of the placenta, she started to bleed profusely.  Which among the following should not be used to control bleeding?
questions.solution:
The given scenario indicates postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in a primigravida with rheumatic mitral stenosis. Methyl ergometrine is contraindicated in patients with organic heart disease.

Contraindications of methyl ergometrine are:

  • Twin pregnancy - Second baby gets compromised by tetanic contractions of uterus if given after delivery of first baby
  • Organic cardiac disease - Causes overloading of right heart by squeezing blood from uterine circulation.
  • Severe pre-eclampsia and eclampsia
  • Rh negative mother -  Increases chance of fetomaternal transfusion.
